title: Enter Quarto
text: Your turn!

title: Enter Quarto

Exercise 1
 

Go to the Exercise section ‚úèÔ∏è

title: Enter Quarto
text:
Markdown syntax


You don‚Äôt need special software to read it
Separates out the content and structure from the document styling
Focus on the content not the way it looks



Markdown-formatted document should be publishable as-is, as plain text, without looking like it‚Äôs been marked up with tags or formatting instructions. - John Gruber

title: Enter Quarto
text:
Text formats

Formatting text is easy, and follows a common structure by surrounding the text with special characters

*This* **workshop** ~~will be~~ is `so` [cool!]{.underline} [Yay!]{.smallcaps}
gives:
This workshop will be is so cool! Yay!

title: Enter Quarto
text:
Sections

Sections are added to a document using different numbers of #:


# creates a Level 1 heading (section)
## creates a level 2 heading (subsection)
### creates a Level 3 heading (sub-subsection)
And so on‚Ä¶

title: Enter Quarto
text:
Lists


Unordered lists can be created using - (or *):






- Item 1
- Item 2
- Item 3


gives



Item 1
Item 2
Item 3






Ordered lists can be created with progressive numbers or letters:






1. Item 1
2. Item 2
3. Item 3


gives



Item 1
Item 2
Item 3

title: Enter Quarto
text:
Links

Add a link using square brackets and round brackets:

the text to appear in square brackets
followed by the URL in round brackets


A link to the [Quarto documentation](https://quarto.org/).
which gives:
A link to the Quarto documentation.

title: Enter Quarto
text:
Images

Add an image using ![](path/image.png).

You can add a caption easily within the brackets as such ![Cool image](path/image.png)






Tip



Use relative file paths rather than absolute file paths - other people won‚Äôt share the same absolute file path as you!
File paths are relative to where the Quarto document is!

title: Enter Quarto
text:
There is much more‚Ä¶
  
For further reading on this part, visit the Quarto documentation on Markdown Basics.
For quick help in the syntax, click in the top navigation bar in Rstudio Help > Markdown Quick Reference for a guide.

title: Enter Quarto
text:
Exercise 2
 

Go to the Exercise section ‚úèÔ∏è

title: Enter Quarto
text:
Code chunks


Code blocks are the main way of including executable R code in a document.
Code blocks always start with three backticks, followed by the an r in curly brackets.



```{r}
2 + 2
```

[1] 4

title: Enter Quarto
text:
Code chunk options
Code chunk options can control:

whether your code is executed
whether your code is displayed
if warnings and errors are displayed
how figures are presented
how tables are presented

title: Enter Quarto
text:
Code chunk options

They are included in a special comment at the top of the chunk prefaced with #|:


```{r}
#| output: true
2 + 2
```

[1] 4

title: Enter Quarto
text:
Code chunk options
 







Option
Description




eval
Evaluate the code chunk


echo
Include the source code in output


output
Include the results of executing the code


warning
Include warnings in the output


error
Include errors in the output (errors won‚Äôt halt document processing)


include
Prevent any output (code or results) from being included

title: Enter Quarto
text:
Code chunk options: fig-



```{r}
#| warning: false
#| fig-align: center 
#| fig-width: 6
#| fig-asp: 0.9
#| fig-cap: "Distribution of bill depth sizes"
#| output-location: column

ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = bill_depth_mm)) +
  geom_density() +
  theme_bw()
```





Distribution of bill depth sizes

title: Enter Quarto
text:
Code block options: tbl- , eq-

For tables, it is exactly the same as for figures, but instead of fig-, you replace it is tbl-.
For equations it is similar but with eq-.

title: Enter Quarto
text:
Code block options: tbl- , eq-

```{r}
#| tbl-align: center 
#| tbl-cap: "First 5 rows and columns of the penguins dataset"

knitr::kable(head(penguins[,1:5]))
```


First 5 rows and columns of the penguins dataset

bill_depth_mm

title: Enter Quarto
text:
Code chunk options: label
 
You can add a label to each code chunk

This allows you to:

associate an ‚Äúlabel‚Äù with an error (if one occurs)
cross-reference a figure in the text.

title: Enter Quarto
text:
Code block options: label

To cross-reference, supposing the label of the code chunk is:


#| label: fig-billdepthdist


you simply write in the text as:

Many penguins in the dataset seem to have a bill depth between 18 and 19mm ([@fig-billdepthdist]).

title: Enter Quarto
text:
Code block options: label

Many penguins in the dataset seem to have a bill depth between 18 and 19mm (Figure¬†1).


```{r}
#| fig-cap: "Distribution of bill depth sizes"
#| label: fig-billdepthdist
#| output-location: column

ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = bill_depth_mm)) +
  geom_density() +
  theme_bw()
```








Figure¬†1: Distribution of bill depth sizes

title: Enter Quarto
text:
Inline code

You can include executable expressions inside the markdown (text) by enclosing the expression in `r `:

The penguins dataset is composed of 344 observations. 
gives:
The penguins dataset is composed of 344 observations.

This is very useful for automating reports!

title: Enter Quarto
text:
There is much more‚Ä¶

For more on each part of this sections:

Executions Options - Quarto for more on code chunk options
Cross References ‚Äì Quarto for more on labels and cross-referencing
Tables - Quarto for more on tables
Technical Writing - Quarto for more on equations and technical writing
Inline Code ‚Äì Quarto for more on inline codes

For more advanced notions on coding aspects in Quarto, visit HTML Code Blocks ‚Äì Quarto

Projects

Presentations (like this one today)
Manuscripts

You‚Äôll find everything at the official Quarto - Documentation.

title: Reproducible Research
text:
What does reproducibility mean actually?


 


Difficult question to answer‚Ä¶

No clear definition ‚û°Ô∏è varies between the disciplines

title: Reproducible Research
text:
What does reproducibility mean actually?


 

Difficult question to answer‚Ä¶
‚ÄúLack of reproducibility‚Äù ‚û°Ô∏è understood but broad expression
No clear definition ‚û°Ô∏è varies between the disciplines





Gundersen Odd Erik 2021 The fundamental principles of reproducibility Phil. Trans. R. Soc. A.37920200210 DOI:¬†10.1098/rsta.2020.0210.

title: Reproducible Research
text:
What does reproducibility mean actually?



Direct reproducibility (commonly ‚Äòreplication‚Äô or ‚Äòexperimental reproducibility‚Äô)




Analytical reproducibility (commonly ‚Äòcomputational reproducibility‚Äô)




Systemic reproducibility (commonly ‚Äòrobustness‚Äô)




Conceptual reproducibility (commonly ‚Äògeneralisation‚Äô)






Schloss, 2018. DOI: 10.1128/mbio.00525-18


National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine. 2019. Reproducibility and Replicability in Science. Washington, DC: The National Academies Press. DOI: 10.17226/25303

title: Reproducible Research
text:
What does reproducibility mean actually?



Direct reproducibility (commonly ‚Äòreplication‚Äô or ‚Äòexperimental reproducibility‚Äô)




Analytical reproducibility (commonly ‚Äòcomputational reproducibility‚Äô)




Systemic reproducibility (commonly ‚Äòrobustness‚Äô)




Conceptual reproducibility (commonly ‚Äògeneralisation‚Äô)









Schloss, 2018. DOI: 10.1128/mbio.00525-18


National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine. 2019. Reproducibility and Replicability in Science. Washington, DC: The National Academies Press. DOI: 10.17226/25303

title: Reproducible Research
text:
In other words‚Ä¶
 


Data


Code


Documentation

title: Reproducible Research
text:
In other words‚Ä¶
 








Reproducible Research

title: Reproducible Research
section: Why are we talking about this now?
text:
Why are we talking about this now?










Baker, M. 1,500 scientists lift the lid on reproducibility. Nature 533, 452‚Äì454 (2016). DOI: 10.1038/533452a.






70% of researchers can‚Äôt reproduce others‚Äô findings
60% can‚Äôt reproduce their own findings
Non-reproducible biomedical research costs $28 billion/year (Freedman et al.¬†2015)

title: Reproducible Research
section: How important is it? Well, quite important
text:
How important is it? Well, quite important
 


Anyone (with a similar level of skills) should be able to do reproduce your research and benefit from it
Funders (e.g., ANR) and journals now require data and code accessibility, which aligns with the growing open-science movement
If I keep my data and code, I have a competitive advantage
If I share my data and code, my work will gain more visibility (and citations üòé)

title: Reproducible Research
text:
Advantages
 


It obliges you to verify your work (by sharing both docs, data and code)
Your future self will thank you (you‚Äôll be much more productive)
Your collaborators too
By ensuring reproducibility, you reinforce your credibility and reputation
Reproducibility fosters trust in scientific progress and accelerates it

title: Reproducible Research
section: What sources of irreproducibilitycan you think of? ü§î
text: What sources of irreproducibilitycan you think of? ü§î

title: Reproducible Research
text:
Factors decreasing reproducibility


  

Failures of reproducibility cannot be traced to a single cause
Nearly every aspect of a study needs to be considered









Baker, M. 1,500 scientists lift the lid on reproducibility. Nature 533, 452‚Äì454 (2016). DOI: ¬†10.1038/533452a.

title: Reproducible Research
text:
Example: a drawing protocol

You really want to draw something but don‚Äôt know how. You‚Äôve found this protocol in a very prestigious journal and want to reproduce it. Grab your pens and papers üìù !




Switch Language



Draw a large circle in the center of your page.
Inside the circle, slightly above the middle, draw two medium-sized ovals next to each other. Inside each oval, draw a smaller filled-in oval.
Below the ovals, in the center of the circle, draw a small upside-down triangle.
On top of the circle, draw two small triangles with the base of each triangle touching the edge of the circle and the points facing outward.
From the bottom point of the triangle, draw two curved lines that extend outward, one curving to the left and one to the right, forming a ‚ÄúW‚Äù shape.
On each side of the curved lines, draw three short straight lines extending outward.




Dessinez un grand cercle au centre de votre page.
√Ä l‚Äôint√©rieur du cercle, l√©g√®rement au-dessus du milieu, dessinez deux ovales de taille moyenne c√¥te √† c√¥te. √Ä l‚Äôint√©rieur de chaque ovale, dessinez un petit ovale rempli.
Sous les ovales, au centre du cercle, dessinez un petit triangle invers√©.
Au-dessus du cercle, dessinez deux petits triangles avec la base de chaque triangle touchant le bord du cercle et les pointes dirig√©es vers l‚Äôext√©rieur.
√Ä partir de la pointe inf√©rieure du triangle, dessinez deux lignes courb√©es qui s‚Äô√©tendent vers l‚Äôext√©rieur, l‚Äôune courbant vers la gauche et l‚Äôautre vers la droite, formant une forme en ‚ÄúW‚Äù.
De chaque c√¥t√© des lignes courb√©es, dessinez trois petites lignes droites qui s‚Äô√©tendent vers l‚Äôext√©rieur.







Inspired by Repro4Everyone. (n.d.). Introduction to Reproducibility. Repro4Everyone. Retrieved January 30, 2025.

text:

Document practices (e.g., lab notebooks, ELNs with eLabFTW)
Organise code, data and files (e.g., separate folders for different data, clear filenames, tidy principles)

section: How can we be bit more reproducible?
text:

Document practices (e.g., lab notebooks, ELNs with eLabFTW)
Organise code, data and files (e.g., separate folders for different data, clear filenames, tidy principles)
Share data and outputs

title: Reproducible Research
section: How can we be bit more reproducible?
text:
How can we be bit more reproducible?


Document practices (e.g., lab notebooks, ELNs with eLabFTW)
Organise code, data and files (e.g., separate folders for different data, clear filenames, tidy principles)
Share data and outputs
Track changes (= versionning)

title: Reproducible Research
section: How can we be bit more reproducible?
text:
How can we be bit more reproducible?


Document practices (e.g., lab notebooks, ELNs with eLabFTW)
Organise code, data and files (e.g., separate folders for different data, clear filenames, tidy principles)
Share data and outputs
Track changes (= versionning)
Learn to code (even a little)




Artwork by Allison Horst

title: Reproducible Research
text:
What is Literate programming?



Introduced by Donald Knuth in 1984
Idea of combining source code and text
Method for writing computer programs as literary essays
Many tools exist for various languages:

RMarkdown (R)
Jupyter (Python)
Quarto (multi-language)






Knuth, Donald Ervin. ‚ÄúLiterate Programming.‚Äù Computer/law journal (1984).





‚ÄúThe best way to communicate from one human being to another is through story‚ÄùDonald Knuth

title: Reproducible Research
text:
What is Quarto?


Quarto is an open-source, scientific and technical publishing system
It implements the concept of literate programming
It provides a unified authoring framework for data science, combining your code, its results, and your prose (text)



Illustration by Alison Hill and Allison Horst, for RStudio

title: Reproducible Research
text:
Advantages of Quarto



Quarto documents are fully reproducible and dynamic
They automate the inclusion of the last versions of the results of an analysis
Allows you to avoid copy + paste, avoid accidental errors and save time
Literally dozens of output formats are available: Web pages, PDFs, Word files, websites, books, and more.
Open source so anyone can use it



Illustration by Alison Hill and Allison Horst, for RStudio

title: Reproducible Research
text:
Main use cases

There can be three relevant use cases:



For communicating to decision-makers or to a more general audience, who want to focus on the conclusions, not the code behind the analysis
For collaborating with other data scientists (including future you!), who are interested in both your conclusions, and how you reached them (i.e.¬†the code)
As an environment in which to do data science, as a modern-day lab notebook where you can capture not only what you did, but also what you were thinking

title: Reproducible Research
section: To advance, we must code a little‚Ä¶
text:
To advance, we must code a little‚Ä¶




Artwork by Allison Horst







CS-WORKSHOP Feb 2025 | Materials: ellfrank7/repro-research-workshop

title: Pre-workshop Instructions
text: To ensure everything runs smoothly on the day of the workshop, we‚Äôll need to set up a few things beforehand.

title: Pre-workshop Instructions
text:
1 Brief Workshop Overview
The workshop will be divided into two parts:

Reproducible Research: An Open Discussion
Literate Programming with Quarto: A Small but Impactful Step

Part 1 will be discussion-based, focusing on the concept of reproducibility, its importance, and the factors contributing to non-reproducibility. There will be practical work also. No prior coding or bioinformatics knowledge is needed here.
Part 2 is hands-on and involves practical work using specific informatic tools. To participate fully, you‚Äôll need to download or update these tools in advance. Don‚Äôt worry‚Äîthey‚Äôre free and easy to set up! Let‚Äôs go!

title: Pre-workshop Instructions
text:
2 General requirements
Please bring the following:

üíª a laptop/computer
‚úèÔ∏è a pencil/pen
üìÑ paper
‚òï a mug (for coffee of course)

If needed, we can provide pencils, paper and even mugs!






No computer? Not a problem



If you are unable to bring your own computer, feel free to do the practical work with or following another participant üëØ. In this case, please send me an email saying so!

title: Pre-workshop Instructions
text:
3 Software requirements
The majority of the practical aspect of the workshop involves a computer, and therefor using specific tools. If you intend on participating fully, you‚Äôll need to download (or update) these tools in advance. Don‚Äôt worry, they‚Äôre free and easy to set up! Let‚Äôs go!


3.1 The scientific and technical publishing system: Quarto
Quarto is an open-source system for scientific and technical publishing, built on Pandoc1. It allows you to create reproducible documents by integrating code, results, and narrative. Outputs can include HTML, PDF, Word, and more.
To use Quarto, you‚Äôll need to install the Quarto CLI, which handles rendering Quarto documents. Download the latest version from the Quarto website and follow the installation instructions.



3.2 The programming language: R
R is a powerful programming language for data science. You can download it for free from The Comprehensive R Archive Network (CRAN). At the top of the CRAN homepage, you‚Äôll find links for different operating systems: Windows, Mac, or Linux.
If you‚Äôre having trouble in orientating the sites, don‚Äôt worry! Below I provide detailed instructions for each operating system:


Download for Windows

To install R on Windows, click the ‚ÄúDownload R for Windows‚Äù link. Then click the ‚Äúbase‚Äù link. Next, click the first link at the top of the new page. This link should say something like ‚ÄúDownload R-4.4.2 for Windows‚Äù, except the 4.4.2 will be replaced by the most current version of R. The link downloads an installer program, which installs the most up-to-date version of R for Windows. Run this program and step through the installation wizard that appears. The wizard will install R into your program files folders and place a shortcut in your Start menu. Note that you‚Äôll need to have all of the appropriate administration privileges to install new software on your machine.



Download for MacOS

To install R on a Mac, click the ‚ÄúDownload R for Mac‚Äù link. Next, click on the R-4.4.2 package link (or the package link for the most current release of R). An installer will download to guide you through the installation process, which is very easy. The installer lets you customize your installation, but the defaults will be suitable for most users. I‚Äôve never found a reason to change them. If your computer requires a password before installing new progams, you‚Äôll need it here.



Download for Linux

R comes preinstalled on many Linux systems, but you‚Äôll want the newest version of R if yours is out of date. The CRAN website provides files to build R from source on Debian, Redhat, SUSE, and Ubuntu systems under the link ‚ÄúDownload R for Linux.‚Äù Click the link and then follow the directory trail to the version of Linux you wish to install on. The exact installation procedure will vary depending on the Linux system you use. CRAN guides the process by grouping each set of source files with documentation or README files that explain how to install on your system.




3.3 The IDE2: Rstudio
RStudio is an application like Microsoft Word‚Äîexcept that instead of helping you write in English or French, RStudio helps you write in R.
You can download RStudio for free. Just click the ‚ÄúDownload RStudio Desktop For [Your OS]‚Äù button and follow the installation steps. Once installed, open RStudio like any other application‚Äîusually by clicking its desktop icon.
When you open RStudio, you‚Äôll see a window with three panes, as shown below: (Figure¬†1):






Figure¬†1: The Rstudio IDE for R






3.4 The toolset: R packages
R packages are collections of functions, data, and documentation that expand R‚Äôs capabilities. To work with Quarto in R, ensure the following packages are installed:

ggplot2
quarto
knitr
rmarkdown

To check and install these packages, run the following code in RStudio (in the console pane, shown on the left of Figure¬†1):

packages <- c("ggplot2", "quarto", "knitr", "rmarkdown")
installed <- packages %in% rownames(installed.packages())

if (any(!installed)) {
  message("Missing some packages...")
  install.packages(packages[!installed])
} else {
  message("Everything is good to go!")
}




3.5 Finish line
If you encounter any issues with downloads or installations, feel free to email me at ellis.franklin@univ-lorraine.fr or visit me directly at the Metz site in the P7 building, office M3.
If you‚Äôve successfully set everything up, you‚Äôre ready for the workshop! Congratulations! üéâ
See you on the 6th of Feb! üêß

(back to top)

title: Pre-workshop Instructions
text:
Footnotes


Pandoc is a tool that converts documents to different formats. Quarto leverages it to convert markdown to a variety of output formats.‚Ü©Ô∏é
Integrated Development Environment‚Ü©Ô∏é

title: Exercises
text:
Exercise 2 - Markdown basics






Note



Before this exercise:

Download the zip file ‚Äòpenguins-template‚Äô thats holds

penguins-template.qmd file
three-penguins.png image

Open the Rstudio and create a new project:

Go to File > New Project, then Browse to the downloaded zip file and Create.

Copy and paste install.packages("palmerpenguins") into the Console and run it.




Open the penguins-template.qmd file in RStudio
Add a Level 2 header titled ‚ÄúData Overview‚Äù after the existing content in the file
Copy and paste the following text into the file:
The `penguins` dataframe contains 344 observations of penguins.
It includes several qualitative variables, including the following:
- Sex of the penguins
- Island where they are found
- Species to which they belong
The represented species are: Chinstrap, Gentoo, and Ad√©lie.
Modify the text so that the final rendering looks like this, with the value 344 inserted using inline code:

The penguins penguins contains 344 observations of penguins. It includes several qualitative variables, including the following:

Sex of the penguins
Island where they are found
Species to which they belong

The represented species are : Chinstrap, Gentoo et Ad√©lie.

Add the image three-penguins.png to your document, then add a caption for this image.

title: Exercises
text:
Exercise 3 - Code blocks and ouputs

Add a code block to generate a table showing the first 5 rows of the penguins dataframe using the knitr::kable() function.







Tip



For those not familiar with R, unfold the following, copy and paste into the document, and render:


Code
knitr::kable(head(penguins))





Add a second code block to generate a figure (using R base or ggplot2) to explore the relationship between the body mass of penguins and the length of their flippers, as well as the differences between species.







Tip



For those not familiar with R, unfold the following, copy and paste into the document and render:


Code
g <- ggplot(penguins, aes(x = flipper_length_mm, 
                              y = body_mass_g)) +
      geom_point(aes(color = species, shape = species), 
                 size = 2, 
                 alpha = 0.7) + 
      scale_color_manual(values = c("darkorange","purple","cyan4")) + 
      labs(x = "Flipper length (mm)", 
           y = "Body mass (g)", 
           color = "Penguin species", 
           shape = "Penguin species") + 
      theme_minimal()

g





Add the following options to the code chunk, one by one. Generate the document after each modification and observe the changes:

echo: false
warning: false

Just below the figure, provide a description of the relationship between the two variables, both overall and for each species.
Modify the size of the figure using the following options, one by one. Re-render the document after each modification and describe how the figure changes:

fig-width: 10
fig-height: 3
out-width: "100%"
out-width: "20%"

Add a label to the figure with the prefix fig-.
Add a caption to the figure using the fig-cap chunk option. Re-render one last time.

Well done! You‚Äôve just created your first Quarto report üéâ !



Artwork from ‚ÄúHello, Quarto‚Äù keynote by Julia Lowndes and Mine √áetinkaya-Rundel, presented at RStudio Conference 2022. Illustrated by Allison Horst.
